awd_titl_txt: OP: Collaborative Research: Development of Advanced Image Reconstruction Methods for Pre-Clinical Applications of Photoacoustic Computed Tomography
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative research project will develop advanced image reconstruction methods for pre-clinical applications of photoacoustic computed tomography (PACT).  PACT is a promising biomedical imaging technique, which has been developed rapidly in the past decade, with applications explored in vascular biology, oncology, neurology, dermatology, gastroenterology, and cardiology.  PACT can circumvent the limitations of many existing approaches and provide detailed three-dimensional anatomical, functional, and molecular information that can facilitate a wide range of biomedical studies.  This research project will dramatically improve image quality in PACT, which will accelerate the widespread adoption of this emerging imaging modality.  The project goals will be accomplished through a collaboration that involves complementary high-level expertise in the mathematical and biomedical imaging sciences.

The project aims at addressing several challenging problems in biomedical imaging in terms of modeling and inversion from both computational and experimental perspectives.  (1) Advanced ultrasound computed tomography (USCT) reconstruction methods will be developed for determination of acoustic heterogeneities.  (2) New photoacoustic computed tomography (PACT) reconstruction methods will be developed to compensate for acoustic heterogeneities.  (3) Novel methods for joint PACT/USCT image reconstruction will be developed to reconstruct the absorbed optical energy density and speed of sound distributions simultaneously.  (4) Innovative PACT reconstruction methods in heterogeneous viscoelastic media will be developed for transcranial brain imaging.  (5) The value of the developed image reconstruction methods will be demonstrated for in-vivo imaging of small animals.  The resulting methods will open new venues for applying these algorithms to wave-related biomedical imaging problems.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this NSF-funded research project was to develop innovative image reconstruction methods for photoacoustic computed tomography (PACT) that will advance the state-of-the-art in preclinical imaging technologies. PACT is an emerging hybrid biophotonic imaging modality that combines the high image contrast of optical imaging methods with the high spatial resolution of ultrasound imaging methods. The project also developed methods for ultrasound computed tomography (USCT) for use with small animal imaging systems.  The outcomes of this research project that address the intellectual merit and broader of impacts of the research are as follows.

Previously available methods for USCT were computationally demanding and the computational burden increases significantly when implemented for 3D imaging. To overcome this issue, we implemented a machine learning method that can map a 3D USCT dataset to its equivalent 2D USCT dataset. The transformed data can then be subsequently employed in a 2D image reconstruction method, allowing us to reconstruct 3D volumes on a slab-by-slab basis with greatly reduced computational cost.  This method may greatly facilitate the application of USCT to preclinical imaging applications that seek to improve diagnostic and therapeutic methods.

There remains an important need for the development of brain imaging methods. A major challenge in transcranial PACT brain imaging is to compensate for aberrations in the measured photoacoustic data due to their propagation through the skull. To address this need, a wave equation-based inversion method was developed that can model the heterogeneous elastic properties of the medium. An iterative image reconstruction method for 3D transcranial PACT was developed that is based on the 3D elastic wave equation. A forward model based on a finite-difference time domain discretization of the elastic wave equation was established. Subsequently, gradient-based methods were employed for computing penalized least squares estimates of the total absorbed optical density distribution. We also developed a joint reconstruction (JR) method for transcranial PACT where the longitudinal and shear speed distributions within the skull are reconstructed concurrently with the sought-after PACT image. These advanced image reconstruction methods will permit transcranial PACT imaging to be accomplished in small animal imaging and ultimately in human subjects.  This will have a great impact on basic science studies of brain diseases and injuries and clinical outcomes for patients. Reconstructed images from both numerical phantoms as well as experimental data were obtained to demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of the approach.

Throughout the project, the developed image reconstruction algorithms were systematically investigated in a multi-tier approach. Initially, the algorithms were tested in an "inverse crime" scenario in which noiseless simulated measurements were produced by use of the same discrete forward model that is assumed by the reconstruction algorithm. This validates that the implementation of the algorithm is correct and that the algorithm performs well under idealized conditions. Next, the algorithms were validated by use of more realistic simulated measurements that contain noise and the effects of modelling errors. Finally, when available, the reconstruction algorithms were evaluated by use of experimental measurement data. Both physical and task-based measures of image quality were employed to quantify algorithm performance.  Additionally, deep-learning-based approaches for quantifying signal detection-based image quality metrics were developed and implemented.

Finally, the project provided opportunities for training new students in the latest computational techniques. The proposed project offered excellent opportunities for two Ph.D. students. The combination of theory and computation was both intellectually challenging and rewarding.
